content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Find an Intermediate-level online course on Coursera about 'Blockchain Technology' which lasts between 1 to 4 weeks, and is provided by a well-known institution. Also, note the course's main goals and the instructor's name.  Please interact with https://www.coursera.org/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: To find an intermediate-level course about 'Blockchain Technology', the next step is to use the search function to look for such courses. The search button is clearly labeled.
Action: Click [2]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.1
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search textbox is now visible at the top. Next, I need to type "Blockchain Technology" into the search box to look for relevant courses.
Action: Type [1]; Blockchain Technology
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I see multiple courses about Blockchain, with their durations, providers, and levels visible. I need to find an intermediate-level course that lasts between 1 and 4 weeks and is from a well-known institution. "Blockchain Applications in Fintech" by INSEAD lasts 1-4 weeks, but it is labeled as "Beginner." The "Blockchain" Specialization by University at Buffalo is "Intermediate," but lasts 3-6 months, which is outside the desired range. I should scroll to see if there are other intermediate-level courses with a 1-4 week duration.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The additional results shown are also beginner-level and have durations longer than 4 weeks (3-6 months). None match the intermediate level and duration of 1 to 4 weeks. I should look for filter options that may allow narrowing by course level and duration to streamline the search.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; up
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.35
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The filter options are on the left sidebar, but only subject and language filters are visible. More filter options might be accessible if I scroll the filter section down, possibly revealing filters for course level and duration.
Action: Scroll [4]; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.4
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The "Learning Product" filter is now visible, but there are still no visible filters for level or duration. To locate these, I should continue scrolling the filter section to see if additional relevant filtering options (like "Level" or "Duration") are available further down.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.45
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I see filters for the type of learning product (Guided Projects, Courses, Projects, Specializations), but still no visible filtering options for course level or duration. The page may have more filters further down; scrolling will help reveal if there is a "Level" or "Duration" filter that can be used to quickly find the desired intermediate, 1-4 week course.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.5
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The displayed courses are mostly beginner level and last between 1 to 3 months, not the required 1-4 weeks. The filters for level or duration still aren't visible, only learning product is shown on the left. To make efficient progress, I should try accessing the "Sort by" filter (top right) if it allows me to sort or filter by course level or duration. This can quickly narrow down appropriate results.
Action: Click [13]
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.55
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The page has navigated to a role-selection interface, which diverges from our course search workflow. To return to browsing/filtering search results for Blockchain courses, it's best to go back to the previous page.
Action: Click [7]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.55
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The interface is still on an onboarding flow/page, not back to the main search results or filters for Blockchain courses. To return effectively to the original search page, the "Exit" button at the top right should be used.
Action: Click [0]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.55
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search results are visible again. "Blockchain Applications in Fintech" by INSEAD meets the duration and institution requirements (1-4 weeks, INSEAD), but is tagged as "Beginner." The other two visible courses are either intermediate but too long, or at the wrong level. I should scroll further down to look for additional results that may be intermediate and fit the 1-4 week range.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.6
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The additional blockchain-related courses listed here are all beginner-level and have durations longer than 4 weeks (3-6 months). There are still no intermediate-level blockchain courses within the 1-4 week range visible. There appear to be no results matching all criteria so far. I should scroll back up and reconsider the best matches among those already surfaced, or look for additional filter options if any are present near the top of the page.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; up
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.65

content:
Thought: After extensive searching, it is clear that there are no intermediate-level courses about Blockchain Technology with a duration of 1-4 weeks from a well-known institution visible in the current results. The closest match to the requirements is "Blockchain Applications in Fintech" by INSEAD (1-4 weeks, well-known institution), but it's labeled as "Beginner." For completeness, I should click into this course to check the main goals and instructor's name, in case its actual content is suitable for a slightly more advanced learner.
Action: Click [35]
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.75

content:
Thought: The main goals of the course "Blockchain Applications in Fintech" are visible: (1) Explain how blockchain transforms key financial functions, and (2) Evaluate real-world blockchain use cases and assess their risks, benefits, and fit for fintech applications. The instructor (Don Tapscott), institution (INSEAD), and duration (1 week) have also been confirmed. Although it's beginner level, it is the closest fit. All required information is now collected.
Action: ANSWER; 
Course: Blockchain Applications in Fintech
Level: Beginner (closest available within 1–4 weeks)
Duration: 1 week (at 10 hours a week)
Institution: INSEAD (well-known)
Instructor: Don Tapscott (+2 more)
Course Main Goals:
1. Explain how blockchain transforms key financial functions from payments to identity, compliance, and tokenization.
2. Evaluate real-world blockchain use cases and assess their risks, benefits, and fit for fintech applications.
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 1.0
